attributes.title: Illinois Tool Works Is Not Your Typical Industrial Stock
summary: Illinois Tool Works has found a way to turn zero sales growth into rising operating income and strong free cash flow.
The company uses its cash to maintain a long and strong dividend growth streak and to reduce shares outstanding.
Investors who aren't long yet should put this stock on their watchlist as I consider it to be a great buy during corrections.

attributes.content:
I have made a huge mistake. I treated Illinois Tool Works (NYSE:ITW) as a 'basic' industrial supplier in the past, using it as a macro trading vehicle. Technically, there's nothing wrong with that. However, the company is much more than that. Not only is the company a dividend aristocrat, but the company is also a dividend king with 50+ years of consecutive dividend hikes. In this article, I am going to discuss the dividend stock Illinois Tool Works, and why I put the stock on my watchlist.

Source: Illinois Tool Works

What's ITW?

Illinois Tool Works is a $63 billion market cap industrial player located in Glenview, Illinois. The company has roughly 45,000 employees, 18,000 granted and pending patents, and operations in 55 countries. The company generates 53% of its sales in North America, 28% in EMEA countries, and 19% in APAC countries.

ITW is more than an auto supplier as only 22% of its sales are generated in the automotive industry. The company has exposure across multiple industries as the overview below shows.

Source: Illinois Tool Works

A large component of the company's business model is customer-back innovation, which means that the company does not simply produce in-house innovation through i.e. R&D, followed by finding customers for its advanced technologies. What ITW does is working together with key customers. This ensures a better relationship with customers and allows the company to invest in the right areas, which will eventually end up increasing R&D efficiency. This is actually a trend that has been going on for years. I studied the process and benefits of supplier-customer relations during my master's and ITW might be one of the best examples of this. If you want more info on this topic, feel free to read this article. Note that it's one of many examples, and a paywall may apply.

2020 Was Bad, But A Good Example Of ITW's Strengths

With that being said, 2020 was bad. Almost all capital expenditure ("CapEx") intensive industries were hit hard by lower demand - at least the industries that ITW services.

In 2020, total sales declined by 11% to $12.6 billion. This decline was caused by a decline of 10% in organic growth and divestitures that were responsible for another 100 basis points. As the graph below shows, 2020 was the second straight year of lower sales after the global economic peak of 2018. Back then, sales peaked at $14.8 billion. Another thing worth mentioning is that sales haven't gone anywhere for roughly 14 years. Even 2018 wasn't higher than 2010 when the global economy started to heat up again.

Source: TIKR.com

Operating income, however, has not gone sideways. Thanks to cost-cutting measures and overall efficiency enhancement, the company has managed to grow margins significantly. During the 2018 peak, operating margins were at 24.4%, which was 10 points higher compared to 2010. Unfortunately, the recent decline in global growth has pushed margins down to 22.9%, which resulted in a total operating income of $2.9 billion.

Source: TIKR.com

Keep in mind that margins would have been much worse if it weren't for 120 basis points tailwinds from enterprise initiatives. That's why, going forward, the company is positive that it can achieve operating margins of 24% to 25% in 2021 with support from another 100 basis points in enterprise initiatives. That said, the company also expects between 7% and 10% in organic sales growth, which should lead to 9%-12% total sales growth to at least $13.7 billion in sales.

With that in mind, the good news is that the company has a long history of rising margins and the ability to quickly recover from a year like 2020 if economic growth is able to significantly recover in 2021, which I believe it will.

More good news is that the company has the ability to generate a lot of shareholder value beyond strong capital gains - this is the part I missed in the past.

Despite being highly cyclical, ITW is currently generating $2.6 billion in free cash flow (2020 result). This is one of the highest results ever and one of the benefits from lower CapEx. Expectations are that free cash flow is going to advance to more than $2.7 billion in 2022 as CapEx is expected to remain subdued.

The graph below shows (partially) what the company does when it generates cash. Note that 2020 is not included as most websites do not have access to 2020 data yet. However, that doesn't matter as I have the data anyway. In 2020, the company spent $706 million on share buybacks. This is down from $1.5 billion in 2019. Dividends were 7% higher bringing total shareholder distributions to roughly $2.1 billion. This is down from $2.8 billion in 2019 when the company distributed more cash than it made in free cash flow. Note that dividends per share have grown by 7.8% CAGR since 2004.

Source: TIKR.com

This is one of the reasons why the company's financial situation has deteriorated. In 2020, excess cash flow was used to lower net debt by roughly $400 million. This was the first (significant) decline since 2012. Meanwhile, total equity (assets minus liabilities) are up almost $200 million, but still well below its multi-year highs. Nonetheless, and this is important, the company remains in excellent financial health. Net-debt/equity is at just 1.7x while EBIT is covering interest expenses 14x.

Source: TIKR.com

Unfortunately, the stock isn't cheap.

Valuation

Let's start by mentioning that the company's 2.2% yield is not at multi-year lows. While it is well off the 2020 highs of 3.5%, it's roughly 60 basis points above its 2018 lows. Unfortunately, it gets worse from here. The company is trading at 30.8x LTM earnings and 21.4x EBITDA (18.9x NTM EBITDA).

I put ITW on my long-term watchlist as I am willing to start a significant position as soon as the stock sells off more than 20%. This almost inclusively happens during a (manufacturing) recession and has happened 4 times since the Great Financial Crisis.

Source: FINVIZ

Normally, long-term investing should not be dependent on timing as most investors are bad at timing. However, ITW is a perfect stock to buying during a severe sell-off. As much as I like dividend growth and free cash flow, I am not forced to put money to work. Besides that, I am already overweight industrials, which means some of my next purchases will be defensive (among others).

This brings me to my final thoughts.

Takeaway

Illinois Tool Works is more than an industrial supplier. The company has figured out a way to consistently improve margins throughout multiple cycles and generate free cash flow of more than 100% of net income. The company uses this cash to maintain its 50+ year dividend growth streak and to buy back shares. And even though net debt has risen until 2020, the company's balance sheet is extremely healthy and leaves room for new investments - if needed.

Unfortunately, the stock isn't cheap after its rally in 2020. Therefore, I suggest that investors who aren't long the stock put this stock on their watchlist. While time in the market generally speaking beats timing the market, I highly value having a list of great stocks on a watchlist to go bargain hunting whenever the market offers us new opportunities.

Let me know what you think!

Thank you very much for reading. Please make sure to click the like button and subscribe if you don't want to miss any updates. All long-term holdings are listed in my Seeking Alpha bio.

attributes.description: iREIT®+HOYA Capital helps members build a sustainable real estate portfolio for steady income generation. In addition to REITs, the service focuses on real income-producing asset classes: ETFs, closed-end funds, preferreds, homebuilders, and dividend champions across various investing vehicles. Members gain access to an extensive suite of Investment Research Trackers and Dividend Tools including data on more than 200 REITs, targeting dividend yields of up to 10%.
